;在中国不间断地生活了三年半之后，今年夏天是我第一次有机会回到阳光明媚的南佛罗里达州探望家人和朋友。我在搬到中国之前卖掉了我的车，所以这是我第一次在没有自己的汽车的情况下回到美国。

;

;Uber行程价格高得离谱，公交线路覆盖率很低，而且我给朋友和家人叫车带来的麻烦让我想知道在美国的人如何能够没有车生活。

;

;在上海的这些年，我从来没有拥有一辆车的需要。上海拥有 19 条线路、全长 802 公里的地铁系统，是一种令人难以置信的出行方式。与我在南佛罗里达州的生活相比，它不仅节省了我的钱，而且由于步行更多，它还让我更健康。

;

;在上海以外的地方旅行时，我不会像在美国那样乘坐飞机或开车很长的距离，而是乘坐火车。中国的传统火车和高铁系统已经足够发达，快捷且非常方便。

;

;我在中国待了很长时间回到美国，这表明美国应该效仿中国，大力投资公共交通。投资公共交通可以推动美国的经济增长。通过扩大公共交通基础设施，美国可以在建筑、运营和维护方面立即创造数百万个就业机会。

;

;此外，便捷的公共交通将低收入者与就业中心连接起来，使他们能够获得以前无法获得的工作。这种包容性不仅可以改善个人生计，还可以扩大劳动力整体规模，提高生产力并推动长期经济增长。

;

;汽车拥有成本对美国家庭来说是一个重大的经济负担。转向公共交通将减轻中产阶级家庭与汽车相关的巨额费用，例如燃油、保险和维护费用。这些盈余收入可以用于消费支出，为当地企业注入活力，从根本上提振经济。

;

;采用像中国这样的公共交通系统提供了可持续的解决方案，有助于应对气候变化并创造更美丽的环境。通过更大规模地采用公交车、地铁和火车，美国可以显着减少碳足迹，为子孙后代带来更清洁的空气和更健康的地球。

;

;此外，公共交通网络消除了对大型停车场的需求，从而实现了城市复兴和绿色空间的创造。将这些混凝土荒地改造成公园、花园和社区中心可以增强我们城市的美丽和宜居性。

;

;强大的公共交通系统可以极大地改善流动性、连通性和整体福祉。高效的公共交通提供了实惠且便捷的出行选择，使家庭能够更轻松地团聚，并促进社区之间的联系。它还鼓励国内旅游，让个人探索国内不同地区，开阔视野，培养更强的民族团结感。

;

;此外，优先考虑公共交通可以使道路更安全，并减少与交通相关的事故和死亡人数。通过提倡步行和主动通勤到公共交通站点，我们可以鼓励身体活动，克服久坐的生活方式，并为更好的公共卫生结果做出贡献。

;

;2021年，拜登政府通过了一项两党基础设施​​法案，该法案在五年内的新基础设施支出总额超过1万亿美元，其中5500亿美元用于新的交通、宽带和公用事业。

;

;相比之下，中国计划在基础设施建设上花费1.8万亿美元。到2023年，大型基础设施项目，包括交通、扩大能源发电能力以及创建工业园区，将比去年增长17%。不用说，拜登的法案对于美国这样一个庞大的经济体来说还远远不够。

;

;尽管有其历史，美国一直具有务实的倾向，能够从国外汲取伟大的想法并将其适应当地的情况，例如州际高速公路系统。如果美国可以向中国学习一件事，那就是公共交通。

; Sat, 22 Jul 2023 03:50:01 +0800 Where in the world is Qin Gang, and why it matters to US-China diplomacyhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3228565/where-world-qin-gang-and-why-it-matters-us-china-diplomacy?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;美国分​​析人士和前官员表示，考虑到两国领导人预计 11 月会晤之前正在进行的微妙外交舞蹈，中国外交部长秦刚长期缺席公众视野，如果这种情况持续更长时间，可能会对美中关系产生有害影响。

;

;与国家主席习近平关系密切的秦刚自 6 月 25 日以来一直没有在公开场合露面，这引发了围绕中美关系的谣言和令人头痛的谣言。世界。中国官方将其缺席归因于未具体说明的“健康原因”。

;

;但本周，外交部拒绝在每日新闻发布会上提供有关秦的状况的信息，然后从官方记录中删除了这个问题，从而加深了谜团。

;

;“对我来说，这揭示了我们对中国精英政治的了解是多么的少，”亚洲协会政策研究所常务董事罗里丹尼尔斯说。 “在议程上的一个议题大概是习近平是否会来美国参加 11 月的亚太经合组织峰会时，无法接触到中国外交部长无疑是一个尴尬的时机。”

;

;到目前为止，中国共产党外交政策负责人王毅 — — 在 12 月底秦上任之前一直担任外交部长 — — 已介入重要会议，包括印度尼西亚外长区域聚会和美国高级官员的访问。

;

;虽然人事问题是一个问题分析人士表示，在国内问题上，秦的外交事务使这一缺席具有更大的全球意义，而且正值中美两国一直在努力修复历史上的不良关系之际。

;

;去年 11 月，习近平和美国总统乔·拜登在印度尼西亚制定了一份路线图，其中包括部长级访问的“阶梯”，旨在在亚太经合组织峰会之前建立信心。

;

;但在 2 月初，一个穿越北美的中国监视气球被击落后，这一阶梯失去了一个梯级，这表明中美关系脆弱。美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯（秦国的同行）将原定的北京之行推迟了四个月。这反过来又压缩了后续访问的时间表，而秦的长期缺席可能会进一步阻碍中国官僚机构重组的工作。

;

;“健康原因”：中国外交部长秦刚将缺席东盟会议

;

;“协议对中国人总是比对外国人更重要，”中国月亮战略咨询公司负责人杰弗里·穆恩(Jeffrey Moon)表示。 “外交部长会权衡一些重要问题。”

;

;传统上，外交部长负责监督重要双边会议的大部分安排。通常他办公桌上的直接考虑因素是邀请哪位美国官员（如果有的话）在北京参加会议。

;

;据报道，继布林肯于6月18日至19日访问、财政部长珍妮特·耶伦于7月6日至9日访问以及气候特使约翰·克里本周刚刚结束的访问之后，商务部长吉娜·雷蒙多将是下一个。

;

;秦退出预计不会影响美中关系的更广泛范围。布鲁金斯学会高级研究员瑞安·哈斯表示：“如果我们假设秦刚不会回来，他一直是中国战略的实施者和阐明者，而不一定是中国战略的设计者。”

;

;“显然，拜登政府投入了时间和精力来与秦刚建立关系，但这种关系将会消失。但我们可以假设王毅会弥补这一不足。我们已经和他打交道很长时间了。”

;

;即便如此，任何离开都可能削弱中国在全球的外交影响力，直到选出替代者，因为北京现在只有一名高级官员（而不是两名）代表其参加重要的外国会议。

;

;此外，礼宾细节也有其分量：布林肯抵达北京时没有走红地毯，他与习近平的会面相当冷静和正式。耶伦受到了更热情的接待，但没有会见习近平，克里也没有会见——相反，习近平在访问期间发表了讲话，取代了克里与同行的任何会谈。

;

;“中国的礼节极其重要，他们对待布林肯的方式必须在比工作层面更高的水平上进行评估，”前美国驻成都总领事文在寅表示。 “那么与美国接触的策略是什么？”

;

;大多数分析人士认为，秦国离开的可能性越来越大，也可能影响其他外交和官僚问题。秦上任前曾担任中国驻美国大使，他与外国同行建立了必须重建的个人关系。

;

;他的外交部盟友也可能被取代，从而造成官僚动荡，而其他决策，从新大使馆的资助到设施管理和员工福利，可能会被推迟。

;

;分析师表示，习近平与拜登阶梯的另一个目标也面临风险：举行工作级别会议可能会在任何 11 月的峰会上达成协议。

;

;虽然拜登政府不太可能在降低前唐纳德·特朗普政府征收的关税方面做出让步，但谈判可能会在其他问题上放缓——比如减少签证要求，以及更多的人员往来和直航——如果两位领导人会面，这些问题将提供“可交付成果”。

;

;美国也必须做出调整。巴拉克·奥巴马政府期间担任国家安全委员会中国、台湾和蒙古主任的哈斯表示，白宫可能会试图弄清楚哪些沟通渠道仍然开放，以及哪些中国官员将推进这一进程。

;

;“可以肯定地说，人们可能对正在发生的事情非常好奇。”

;

;周五，在广泛讨论中国相关问题时，布林肯拒绝就秦缺席的问题发表评论：“我会留下这个问题”

;

;如果中国未能干预朝鲜，美国将采取行动：布林肯

;

;中国长期以来经常出现官方突然且不明原因缺席的情况，尤其是在北京反腐败运动最激烈的时期。但鉴于秦是中国的外在形象，尽管他的级别较低，但他比习近平或王更多地出现在国外，这一点变得更加明显。

;

;“在当今的中国，高级官员的个人生活保密或他们从公众视野中消失都不是闻所未闻的，”风险咨询公司Erelas的副经理布洛克·埃尔达尔(Brock Erdahl)说，他援引了习近平在2012年莫名其妙缺席两周的情况，同时也是公安部副部长兼国际刑警组织主席。孟宏伟于 2018 年 9 月失踪，一年后再次出现在腐败审判中。

;

;负责监控中国宣传的埃尔达尔指出，北京审查机构一反常态地允许一些关于秦失踪的网上讨论，导致公众舆论超过任何官方解释。

;

;“谣言往往会填补官方沉默造成的空白，导致整体叙述至少暂时脱离北京在国内外的控制。 ”，埃尔达尔补充说，这可能会给中国的外交战略带来不确定性。

;

;关于其原因的猜测甚嚣尘上，从所谓的婚外情到政治内讧，再到真正的疾病。据报道，外交部附近的建筑表明秦可能需要无障碍入口。

;

;德国马歇尔基金会亚洲项目主任邦妮·格拉泽 (Bonnie Glaser) 表示：“这表明人们只是在摸索任何东西。”

;

;欧盟外交事务负责人何塞普·博雷尔 (Josep Borrell) 着眼于 10 月份的中国之行

;

;虽然双方都对稳定关系感兴趣，但分析人士表示，美国官员前往中国的单程游行表明主场优势更为重要。

;

;虽然大多数部长级会议都在北京举行，但预计秦将在习近平与拜登坐下来敲定细节之前不久访问华盛顿。

;

;对于北京来说，重要的是要确保习近平被视为受人尊敬的全球领导人，并且不会因任何意外要求或不良宣传而感到尴尬。

;

;白宫希望表明拜登能够负责任地处理这一至关重要的关系，这与他的共和党同行形成鲜明对比。 2024 年选举日益临近。双方还必须预见并应对台湾即将在一月举行的总统选举。

;

;“在可预见的未来，这将是一个复杂而混乱的局面，”哈斯说。

;

;;

;美国最高外交官周五表示，如果中国拒绝干预朝鲜的军事部署，美国将采取行动。朝鲜是一个隐士国家，也是北京的盟友，美国长期以来一直指责朝鲜在东亚发挥破坏稳定的作用。

;

;美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯表示，他已告诉中国同行，华盛顿希望北京帮助处理朝鲜“核计划”和核问题清理朝鲜半岛。他表示，如果中国不干预，美国将加强与日本和韩国的防务联盟。

;

;布林肯在美国科罗拉多州阿斯彭安全论坛的炉边谈话中针对中国发表了讲话，他说：“我们相信你们拥有独特的影响力，我们希望你们利用它来获得朝鲜更好的合作。”

;

;“但如果你们不能或不愿意，那么我们将不得不继续采取措施，不是针对中国，但中国可能不会喜欢，因为这不仅会加强和支撑我们自己的防御，还会加强和支撑韩国和日本的防御，并深化我们三国共同开展的工作。

;

;北京批评华盛顿在东亚的防务联盟，将其视为监视或遏制中国军事的努力。首尔和东京对平壤的军事试验感到不满，这些试验有时在其领空附近进行。

;

;朝鲜已经进行了“一次又一次的导弹发射”，布林肯说。 7 月 12 日，平壤对其 Hwasong-18 洲际弹道导弹进行了第二次飞行测试。

;

;朝鲜的共产主义邻国中国过去曾向朝鲜提供燃料和粮食援助，并就该国的军事化问题促成国际对话。

;

;布林肯发表此番言论之前，周二，美国士兵特拉维斯·金 (Travis King) 失踪。国务卿表示，他没有关于金的下落的最新消息，但“肯定有人担心”他可能会在朝鲜遭受酷刑。

;

;中国不会“鼓励”朝鲜，即使它在安全危机中着眼于加深关系

;

;布林肯周五表示，美国现在正在努力巩固不断恶化的中美关系。他、美国财政部长珍妮特·耶伦和总统乔·拜登的气候特使约翰·克里都在过去两个月内访问了中国。

;

;这位外交官表示：“对我们来说，重要的是让这种关系恢复一定的稳定性，为其奠定基础，确保我们显然所处的竞争不会演变成冲突，而这首先要从接触开始。”

;

;布林肯表示，中国可以帮助阻止非法毒品芬太尼的生产，这些芬太尼通过墨西哥到达美国，控制全球气候变化，并允许释放美国被拘留者。

;

;他说：“如果我们不参与，我们就会被贴上不负责任的标签。”

;

;中国王毅呼吁“基辛格式外交智慧”

;

;但挑战依然存在，布林肯周五表示，美国已开始对中国黑客入侵美国政府电子邮件的报道进行正式调查。

;

;华盛顿的电子邮件账户据美国有线电视新闻网 (CNN) 和《华尔街日报》援引的消息人士称，据报道，美国驻北京大使和国务院负责东亚和太平洋地区事务的高级官员遭到了入侵。

;

;“我们有时不止一次与中国分享的是，我们担心任何针对政府、公民、公司的行为都是我们真正关心的问题，”布林肯说。 “我们今后将根据需要采取适当行动。”

;

;北京国营《中国日报》7月13日称美国为“世界上最大的黑客帝国和全球网络窃贼”，并表示当前的黑客指控“只不过是美国玷污中国形象的老把戏”。

;

;一年一度的阿斯本安全论坛是由政策机构阿斯本战略集团组织的外交政策会议。

; Sat, 22 Jul 2023 03:20:02 +0800 Retired Canadian police officer William Majcher charged with helping China ‘intimidate’ individualhttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3228563/retired-canadian-police-officer-william-majcher-charged-illegally-helping-china?utm_source=rss_feed

;加拿大皇家骑警表示，一名退休警官周五被指控外国干涉罪，指控他帮助中国“识别和恐吓加拿大法律范围之外的人”。

;

;加拿大指责中国试图通过各种计划干涉其事务，包括非法警察局和针对立法者。

;

;北京强烈否认所有此类指控。

;

;加拿大皇家骑警在一份声明中表示，60 岁的 William Majcher“据称利用他的知识和在加拿大的广泛人脉网络获取情报或服务，以造福于中华人民共和国”。它没有提供细节。

;

;加拿大皇家骑警表示，来自香港的 Majcher 被指控犯有阴谋和为外国实体谋取利益的行为。

;

;它补充说，这两项指控源于 2021 年底开始的一项调查。

;

;中国驻渥太华大使馆没有立即回应置评请求。

;

;加拿大和中国之间的关系多年来一直冷淡。

;

;Cana dian情报部门警告中国正在利用LinkedIn招募间谍

;

;5月，渥太华驱逐了一名中国外交官，原因是他涉嫌寻求在2021年针对反对派议员张迈克尔(Michael Chong)在香港的家人。

;

;托尼·贝内特 (Tony Bennett) 于周五在纽约去世，他是美国一代经典歌手中的最后一位，他的欢乐精神跨越了几代人，成为跨越七十年的热门音乐人。他已经 96 岁了。

;

;在大乐队定义美国流行音乐的时代长大，Bennett 在 1990 年代开始赢得年轻观众时实现了不可思议的第二次表演 - 不是通过重塑自己，而是通过展示他在高举标准时的纯粹喜悦。

;

;88 岁的 Bennett 于 2014 年通过与 Lady Gaga 的一系列二重唱成为有史以来登上美国专辑排行榜第一名的最年长的人。贝内特的公关西尔维娅·韦纳 (Sylvia Weiner) 宣布，贝内特于 2016 年透露自己被诊断出患有阿尔茨海默氏症，但他在家乡去世，但没有透露死因。

;

;音乐界、政治界和演艺界纷纷向贝内特致敬。

;

;“毫无疑问，他是你见过的最经典的歌手、男人和表演者。”他是无可替代的。我爱他，崇拜他。”埃尔顿·约翰在 Instagram 上写道。

;

;参议员查克·舒默 (Chuck Schumer) 回忆贝内特是“真正的皇后区之子，他的音乐让我们想起了生活中的许多美好事物”。

;

;“谢谢。我们会想念你的。”舒默写道。

;

;托尼·贝内特 (Tony Bennett) 在无线电城举办了一场众星云集的演出，庆祝自己的 90 岁生日

;

;贝内特 (Bennett) 自从职业生涯开始以来就被比作弗兰克·辛纳屈 (Frank Sinatra)，他一开始试图与自己保持距离，但最终还是走上了与早期歌手相同的道路——在夜总会、电视和电影中唱歌。

;

;不过，他的演艺尝试很快就结束了。事实证明，他的天赋就是他的舞台表现力。带着热情的微笑和整洁的西装，他充满热情和流畅的颤音，声音有力、清晰。

;

;从 1951 年录制电影歌曲“Because of You”开始，Bennett 演唱了数十首热门歌曲，包括“Rags to Riches”、“Stranger in Paradise”，以及成为他标志性歌曲的“I Left My Heart in San Francisco”，这为他赢得了 19 项格莱美奖中的两项。

; >;

;但披头士乐队领导的英国入侵最初对这位歌手造成了损失，他的音乐突然听起来古雅而过时。 1979 年，他差点因吸食可卡因过量而死，之后清醒过来并重振事业。

;

;“当说唱或迪斯科出现时，无论当时的新时尚是什么，我并没有试图找到适合整个音乐界风格的东西，”贝内特告诉英国文化杂志 Clash。

;

;“我只是保持自我，真诚地唱歌，并试图对自己保持诚实......幸运的是，它得到了回报。”

;

;

;

;托尼·贝内特（Tony Bennett）——他的艺名是根据演艺界一线明星鲍勃·霍普（Bob Hope）的建议而来的——原名安东尼·多米尼克·贝内代托（Anthony Dominick Benedetto），出生于纽约皇后区的阿斯托利亚社区。他的父亲是一位从意大利南部移民而来的苦苦挣扎的杂货商。

;

;贝内特早年就展现了作为一名艺人的潜力，9岁时在一场仪式上与纽约传奇市长菲奥雷洛·拉瓜迪亚一起唱歌。

;

;“来自伊帕内玛的女孩”歌手阿斯特鲁德·吉尔伯托于 83 岁去世

;

;但他父亲在 10 岁时去世，当时美国仍在努力摆脱大萧条，导致他离开了学校贝内特在二战期间曾在法国和德国服役。但他因咒骂一名南方军官而被降职，该军官反对贝内特在当时实行种族隔离的军队中与一位非裔美国朋友共进晚餐。

;

;作为惩罚，贝内特在服役期间挖掘尸体。但盟军胜利后，贝内特在德国威斯巴登与战友一起等待回家时意外地接触到了音乐。

;

;由于该市的歌剧院仍然完好无损，一支美国陆军乐队每周表演一次节目，并在德国各地的军事广播电台播出。贝内特被任命为乐队的图书管理员，很快就对自己的声音印象深刻，并被任命为四位歌手之一。

;

;“我可以唱任何我想唱的歌，周围没有人告诉我有什么不同，”贝内特后来在他的自传《美好生活》中写道。

;

;当他回到美国时，他通过《退伍军人法案》参加了正式的歌唱课程，该法案涵盖了返回部队的教育费用。

;

;他的经历使贝内特成为一名终生的自由主义者和自由主义者。和平主义者。 20 世纪 50 年代，当他在迈阿密与爵士乐先锋杜克·艾灵顿 (Duke Ellington) 一起演出时，他被激怒了，艾灵顿因酒店内的种族隔离而被禁止参加新闻发布会。

;

;对于一位受欢迎的艺人来说，这是一个危险的举动，他接受了歌手哈利·贝拉方特 (Harry Belafonte) 的邀请，与民权偶像马丁·路德·金 (Martin Luther King Jr) 一起参加 1965 年从阿拉巴马州塞尔玛出发的游行，支持非裔美国人的平等投票权。

;

;“感谢您对金的女儿伯妮斯周五在 Twitter 上写道。

;

;屡获殊荣的歌手、民权活动家哈利·贝拉方特 (Harry Belafonte) 去世，享年 96 岁

;

;贝内特结过三次婚，育有四个孩子，其中包括安东尼娅·贝内特 (Antonia Bennett)，安东尼娅·贝内特 (Antonia Bennett) 追随了他作为流行和爵士标准歌手的道路。

;

;到 1990 年代初，贝内特出现在音乐视频中并演唱热身歌曲十年后，他发行了三张成功的二重唱专辑。在其中一首歌曲中，他与艾米·怀恩豪斯 (Amy Winehouse) 一起演唱了艾米·怀恩豪斯 (Amy Winehouse) 2011 年去世前的最后一张唱片，当时她 27 岁。

;

;他在纽约无线电城音乐厅举行了一场众星云集的音乐会来庆祝自己的 90 岁生日，该音乐会被改编成电视特别节目和专辑。

;

;贝内特在他的最后十年中进行了美国和欧洲巡演，在冠状病毒大流行于 20 日 3 月 11 日在新泽西州停止巡演之前进行了最后一次公开演出。 20.

;

;不久之后，他透露自己在 2016 年被诊断出患有阿尔茨海默氏症。多年来，他一直没有透露自己的病情。

;

;95 岁生日后，Bennett 又举办了两场生日音乐会，再次是在无线电城音乐厅，与 Lady Gaga 合作，演出被宣传为他告别纽约。

;

;“只要有一首歌可以唱，就让音乐播放/我会比春天更年轻，”他低吟道。在他的第一场告别演出中，他演唱了他的民谣“This Is All I Ask”。

;

;“你们一直是一位很好的观众，”贝内特在安可之前说道。 “我喜欢这个观众。”

; Sat, 22 Jul 2023 01:50:01 +0800 Germany’s China strategy reflects the country’s delicate balancing acthttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3228266/germanys-china-strategy-reflects-countrys-delicate-balancing-act?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.22 01:00;
;;

;Looking beneath the veneer of rhetoric in Germany's new China strategy, which accuses Beijing of following a more “assertive” conduct in world affairs, one sees that the strategy is really an act of political balancing short on concrete policies.

;

;The German blueprint went down badly with the Chinese government, with a spokesman saying it “goes against the trend of the time and will only exacerbate the division of the world”.不可能有别的事。北京不能容忍被描绘成政治经济领域的系统性竞争对手、新疆、香港和西藏的人权侵犯者，以及因其在中国海和台湾海峡的军事自信而对世界稳定构成潜在威胁。

;

;借鉴欧盟委员会对中国的批评立场，柏林的新战略重点是与中国“去风险”，而不是脱钩。最终目标是消除对中国的经济依赖，避免最近犯下的错误，例如严重依赖俄罗斯石油和天然气。

;

;社会民主党总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨领导的政府面临的问题是如何将这一理念转化为行动。肖尔茨本质上表示，德国企业应该考虑他们对中国的市场选择。

;

;因此，德国企业应该自行管理风险，而德国政府将与他们合作，让他们意识到对中国经济的严重依赖可能会出现问题。

;

;德国工业界已经深知这一点。中国德国商会上个月发布的一项调查显示，鉴于地缘政治紧张局势和北京方面的自力更生动力，企业对中国商业环境迅速改善的预期较低。

;

;但德国企业是否能够更加独立于中国市场还有待观察。去年，他们在中国投资了创纪录的 115 亿欧元（129 亿美元）。一些人认为，只有通过有针对性的强制性政策才能实现从中国撤退，包括设立国家基金来补偿因去风险而遭受损失的企业。

;

;肖尔茨政府似乎已准备好采取一些具体措施，即使这些措施表现得中立且并非专门针对中国。事实上，据报道，德国内政部正在制定保护该国关键基础设施的措施。此前，德国政府曾有争议地允许中国航运公司中远集团收购汉堡港一个集装箱码头的少数股权，这一问题导致三党执政联盟产生分歧。

;

;将反华举措伪装成与国家无关的监管行动是借鉴欧盟做法的做法。值得注意的是，欧盟委员会计划在今年年底前提出一项提案，以实施更严格的出口管制，加强对入境投资的审查，并建立对外投资的审查机制。

;

;这些措施应该建立在新的反胁迫工具之上，该工具将用于应对中国自2021年以来对立陶宛采取的贸易行动，以及保护欧洲工业免受中国倾销和出口补贴影响的法规。

;

;德国对德国的态度欧盟委员会提出的经济安全战略将暴露其对北京的真实意图。德国承诺对印度-太平洋地区的军事承诺也是如此，这是其对华战略的一部分，有可能激怒中国领导层。

;

;德国军队将首次参加在澳大利亚与其他 12 个国家约 30,000 名军事人员举行的联合演习。澳大利亚和美国之间最大规模的护身军刀演习将于7月22日至8月4日举行。

;

;2021年，一艘德国军舰近20年来首次在南海巡航。去年，13 架德国军用飞机参加了在澳大利亚举行的联合演习，这是欧洲国家和平时期最大的空中行动。

;

;去年 2 月俄罗斯袭击乌克兰后，肖尔茨立即宣布设立一项价值 1000 亿欧元（1100 亿美元）的基金来加强德国的防御。尽管如此，鉴于柏林军队的作战准备状态受到质疑，德国在印度-太平洋地区的军事存在可能只不过是发出政治信号，这对于欧洲战区也是如此。

;

;柏林对华战略是组成政府的三个政党之间的妥协。虽然肖尔茨领导的社会民主党主要将中国视为合作伙伴，但他们的联盟伙伴（绿党和自由民主党）则倾向于将北京更多地视为竞争对手和“制度对手”。

;

;然而，这三个政党都一致认为，中国的合作在应对气候变化等领域不可或缺。 A stable relationship with Beijing could actually be vital in the face of Germany's economic pains.

;

;The tripartite coalition is navigating in dangerous waters, with the German economy struggling to recover from the triple effects of the Covid-19 crisis, high inflation and Russia's war against Ukraine. Recent polls show that the Christian Democrats, the main opposition force in Germany's parliament, are on the rise along with the far-right Alternative for Germany party, which has apparently shifted its approach by taking a more pro-China position.

;

;China is Germany's single largest trading partner.最终，为了支撑国民经济和政府日益不稳定的地位，肖尔茨及其盟友可能需要德国工业增加与中国的业务以及在中国的业务。 For a trade-oriented power like Germany, there will be very little room for an open challenge of Beijing's geopolitical advances – unless the Chinese mainland tries to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait with an armed intervention.

; Sat, 22 Jul 2023 00:50:02 +0800 ‘Untouchable’ hardline pro-war Putin critic Igor Girkin detained in Moscowhttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/russia-central-asia/article/3228557/untouchable-hardline-pro-war-putin-critic-who-had-role-mh17-incident-detained-moscow?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.21 23:23;
;;

;Russian investigators on Friday detained prominent Russian nationalist Igor Girkin, who had publicly accused President Vladimir Putin and the army top brass of not prosecuting the war in Ukraine harshly or effectively enough.

;

;The move, reported by his wife, his lawyer and the RBC news outlet, suggests the authorities have wearied of his criticism of what they call Russia's “special military operation”.

;

;It follows an abortive mutiny last month led by another outspoken critic, Yevgeny Prigozhin, boss of the Wagner mercenary force, who is still free but has sharply curtailed his own verbal attacks.

;

;Girkin, also known as Igor Strelkov, helped Russia annex Crimea from Ukraine in 2014 and then organise pro-Russian militias who took control of part of eastern Ukraine from Kyiv.

;

;He was also handed a life sentence in absentia by a Dutch court in 2022 for his alleged role in the shooting down of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine in 2014, with the loss of 298 passengers and crew.

;

;How Wagner's Prigozhin turned from Putin pal to critic of military

;

;The former Federal Security Service (FSB) officer had been regarded by many as untouchable due to his background and ties to the authorities, but had become more outspoken in recent months.

;

;Girkin announced in May that he and others had set up the “Club of Angry Patriots”, to enter politics to save Russia from what he said was the danger of turmoil due to military failures in Ukraine.

;

;Asked at the time if he was naive to think he could launch a political movement without the assent of the Kremlin, he said: “I hope you would not call me a naive person.”

;

;In one of his most outspoken tirades on July 18, in a post on his official Telegram channel, read by over 760,000 people, Girkin peppered Putin with personal insults and urged him to transfer power “to someone truly capable and responsible”.

;

;In a message posted on Girkin's official Telegram account, his wife, Miroslava Reginskaya, said:

;

;“Today, at about 11.30am, representatives of the Investigative Committee came to our house.我不在家。 Soon, according to the concierge, they took my husband out by his arms and in an unknown direction.”

;

;She said friends had told her Girkin had been charged with extremism. “I do not know anything about my husband's whereabouts, he has not contacted me,” she said.

;

;There was no immediate comment from the authorities. Girkin's lawyer told the state news agency TASS that it was not clear why his client had been detained.

;

;MH17 verdict: Three convicted, one acquitted over Malaysia plane brought down in 2014

;

;RBC, citing two unnamed law enforcement sources, said Girkin's Moscow home was being searched and that he had been detained over a complaint against him made by a former Wagner employee.

;

;Tatiana Stanovaya, founder of the R Politik analysis firm, said the men who run Russia's law enforcement and power ministries had long wanted to arrest Girkin.

;

;“Strelkov [Girkin] had overstepped all conceivable boundaries a long time ago”, she said. “This is a direct outcome of Prigozhin's mutiny: the army's command now wields greater political leverage to quash its opponents in the public sphere”.

;

;Stanovaya said Girkin's detention was a signal that any of the bitterest critics of Moscow's approach to the war could face prosecution.

; Fri, 21 Jul 2023 23:50:02 +0800 Axed China Initiative’s racial profiling legacy haunts scientists in UShttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/3228493/axed-china-initiatives-racial-profiling-legacy-haunts-scientists-us?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.21 23:00;
;;

;Physicist Xiaoxing Xi's life changed forever when a team of armed FBI agents burst into his home in Philadelphia and rounded up his family at gunpoint.

;

;Xi was arrested and charged with sharing sensitive US company technology on May 21, 2015 – three years before the Donald Trump administration launched its controversial China Initiative targeting scientists in the US for perceived connections with Beijing.

;

;The charges against Xi – who was accused of trying to transfer information to China about the design of a pocket heater – were dropped four months later, but not before he lost his position as chairman of the physics department at the Philadelphia-based Temple University.

;

;During the FBI's investigation, Xi was also not allowed to appear on campus, apply for research grants or talk to his students, even privately.

;

;“That's a very traumatic experience,” Xi said. “作为一名科学家，通常不会想到会发生这样的事情，所以这非常令人震惊，没有任何迹象表明类似的事情会发生。 It was a very dramatic experience.”

;

;Xi said the US government's case was based on four emails sent from his Temple University address that had nothing to do with the pocket heater.

;

;China-born US scientist chases damages from FBI over collapsed case

;

;Instead, the messages were about academic collaborations based on Xi's widely published research, a fact confirmed by affidavits provided by leading experts in his field.

;

;Xi's ordeal took place under former president Barack Obama, but the Trump administration's initiative vastly broadened the scope of later investigations into scientists of Chinese heritage in the US.

;

;About 150 academic scientists were openly investigated and two dozen hit with criminal charges before the initiative was eliminated by the justice department in February 2022.

;

;But the scrutiny has never stopped and there is little sign that the Joe Biden administration is doing enough to repair the damage, scientists of Chinese heritage have told researchers.

;

;The China Initiative, touted as a response to “economic espionage” by Beijing, was heavily criticised at the time as “unconstitutional” by the American Civil Liberties Union, which said it was based on racial profiling because it “singled out scientists based on their race, ethnicity or national origin”.

;

;A lasting impact of the initiative is the widespread fear still reported by many scientists with Chinese heritage, according to a study by researchers from Princeton University, Harvard, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).

;

;The study, published last month in the National Academy of Sciences peer-reviewed journal PNAS, found general feelings of fear and anxiety had led many of the scientists to consider leaving the US or refrain from applying for federal grants.

;

;More than 70 per cent of the 1,304 respondents to an online survey run by the researchers from December 2021 to March 2022 said they did not feel safe as an academic researcher of Chinese origin in the US.

;

;The same survey found 65 per cent were worried about collaborations with China, while 45 per cent of respondents who said they had received federal funding in the past preferred to avoid applying for grants. A total of 61 per cent said they had thought about leaving the US.

;

;'Itch gene' scientist joins Shenzhen institute after US lab shut down amid probe

;

;Xi said he understood “perfectly” the fear expressed by the survey's respondents. “从我的角度来看，我担心的是，我每天所做的一切都可能被政府扭曲来指控我。从心理上来说，这是一件非常可怕的事情。 It's making my life very stressful.”

;

;Before he became a target for the FBI, Xi's research was funded by nine federal grants and he had 15 people on his team. Today, Xi receives one grant for a much smaller focus of study, with just one researcher to help him.

;

;“I had a broader research field at that time, but now it's just one subject.我当时做的很多研究现在都没有做，”习近平说。 He added that he now does everything very carefully “so as not to get into trouble”.

;

;Fear mounts that Chinese-American scientists in US are being targeted

;

;MIT mechanical engineering professor Gang Chen – who was arrested in January 2021 under the China Initiative and had his charges dismissed one year later – said he was afraid to apply for federal grants because of anxieties around being racially profiled.

;

;“Basically, I'm done with federal funding,” Chen told NBC Asian America in August. He has also shifted from nanotechnologies with obvious commercial applications to more fundamental research, according to the February edition of Nature.

;

;Another study, published in March by The Review of Higher Education, found a “consistent and statistically significant pattern” of racial profiling of Chinese and other Asian scientists.

;

;The researchers, from the University of Arizona, surveyed about 2,000 scientists from the top US research universities and concluded that concerns about racial profiling remained, despite the end of the China Initiative.

;

;China-born scientist targeted by US 'discovers world's best semiconductor'

;

;“Chinese scientists in the US continue to be investigated as criminals, not based on espionage but oftentimes reduced to tax-related charges,” the researchers said.

;

;Lead author Jenny Lee said there was no sign of “any governmental action to undo the harmful effects” of the China Initiative.

;

;Universities in the US are also in the difficult position of keeping up with disclosure guidelines while continuing to support their scientists in overseas collaborations, according to Lee.

;

;“So institutions are taking on a rather conservative approach, as if the China Initiative is still in effect and they still need to closely monitor conflicts of interest.”

;

;US scientists keep ties with Chinese peers despite crackdown: researcher

;

;The study found that 42 per cent of Chinese scientists feel racially profiled by the US government, compared to 4.7 per cent of non-Asian scientists. The researchers also identified a significant relationship between feeling racially profiled and considering leaving the country.

;

;“To everyday scientists who were seeing these charges on [news] front pages, that gave them a different view of their work, where it wasn't just about research. It was also high-risk research in ways they didn't think about before,” Lee said.

;

;“Many actually believe that it would be less risky to work in China, even under the Chinese Communist Party, than to work in the United States which values academic freedom.”

;

;Scientist exiled from US brain research finds well-funded lab in China

;

;One Chinese-American scientist who recently returned to China, because of the initiative's impact, said the aim of the initiative had been to create fear among scientists, as part of a US effort to contain China's scientific progress.

;

;“[The US] has achieved its purpose.美国的科学家正在返回中国，而中国的科学家则不敢返回美国，”这位科学家表示。由于该话题的敏感性，他要求匿名。 “It's happening every day.”

;

;But some experts argue that cutting off relations with Chinese academia undermines Washington's intention of competing and winning a technology race against Beijing.

;

;US 'China Initiative' stymied scientific innovation, study says

;

;The US National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine warned last year that the approach is likely to “damage and slow the rate of innovation” in the United States more than it will constrain the advances made by other countries.

;

;“In today's interdependent, global innovation system, the greatest threat is that the US will inadvertently weaken its innovation ecosystem while other countries continue to emulate the actions that have historically yielded US advantage in technology development and commercialisation,” its 2022 report said.

;

;For the anonymous scientist now back in China, there is already evidence that “the US has huge, strategic concerns”.

;

;“China has many talents and funding now. In those high-quality journals, about one-third of the authors are Chinese researchers,” he said.

;

;Chinese universities ranked above Oxbridge, Caltech in quality research

;

;At the same time, research grants in the US have failed to keep up with rising costs, remaining broadly unchanged for the past 30 years. A grant that once funded the running of a lab can only provide one researcher now, the scientist said.

;

;China, which has been the largest producer of scientific papers since 2017, recently surpassed the US on another milestone, according to Japan's National Institute of Science and Technology Policy.

;

;A report published by the institute last year showed China was responsible for more of the top 1 per cent of the world's most frequently cited research between 2018 and 2020 than any other country.

;

;China on the rise in academic influence while US declines in impact: survey

;

;Junming Huang, an associate research scholar at Princeton University and co-author of the PNAS study, said the US should “continue to welcome and attract Chinese scientists to maintain [its] global leadership in science and technology in the long run”.

;

;“A key lesson we can learn from the China Initiative is we cannot apply a broad brush to solve problems and apply policies. We need surgical precision and data-based solutions that offer genuine steps moving forward to tackle specific problems,” he said.

;

;Despite the challenges reported by scientists of Chinese heritage in the US, not everyone is returning to China.

;

;Xie Xiaoliang is latest Chinese scientist to give up US citizenship

;

;A PhD candidate at the University of Washington, who asked for anonymity because of the issue's sensitivity, said she would not be going back to China any time soon.

;

;The researcher said it was her personal interest to explore cutting-edge technologies and their diverse directions. “From this point of view, I think the US and Europe remain the most open places at the moment.”

;

;Meanwhile, Xi's efforts to seek redress from the courts for his experience continues.

;

;A lawsuit filed against the lead FBI agent and others in 2017, alleging that they “made knowingly or recklessly false statements” to support their investigation and prosecution was dismissed by a district court in 2021.

;

;Chinese-born professor sues FBI agent over 'spying' arrest

;

;Xi appealed the decision last year and in May the Third Circuit Court of Appeals ruled his case had been wrongfully dismissed. Xi and his family are waiting to see if the US government will appeal the ruling and move the case forward, he said.

;

;In written testimony presented in 2021, Xi said that “whether the US and China are in a cold war or hot war, it is wrong for law enforcement to profile Chinese scientists based on where they come from”.

;

;“All Chinese professors, scientists and students are not non-traditional collectors, or spies, for China,” he said.

;

;AI expert Zhu Songchun to return to China from US

;

;Speaking to the South China Morning Post last week, Xi said the China Initiative had been based on the assumption that Chinese scientists were “suspected of spying for China”.

;

;“That's the fundamental reason for all these cases and all the investigations that have happened … In a sense, 'presumed guilty until proven innocent'. This condition has not changed,” he said.

;

;China has launched an anti-dumping probe into propionic acid from the US, as heavy dependence on American supplies of the widely used chemical ingredient is sounding alarms in the domestic industry.

;

;The probe, which began on Friday, will last at least a year and could be extended until January 21, 2025, under particular circumstances, the Ministry of Commerce said.

;

;Propionic acid is commonly used in foods, pesticides, pharmaceuticals and drug intermediates. It inhibits the growth of mould and some bacteria – acting as a common preservative.

;

;The request for the anti-dumping investigation was filed by the Jiangsu Chemical Industry Association, a major domestic producer that holds more than half of the Chinese market share, and it targets US sales of propionic acid in China from 2019 through the first three months of 2023, the ministry said.

;

;'Only the wearer knows where the shoe pinches': tough times for China's exporters

;

;The probe came against the backdrop of rising US-China tensions, and also after Beijing banned the export of two key metals for semiconductors – germanium and gallium – citing national security concerns. But the move is widely considered a response to the US' growing tech-containment measures targeting China.

;

;Dumping is usually seen when goods enter a country's market during the regular trade process at a price below their normal price in China.

;

;The association said the price of propionic acid in China fell by 28.2 per cent in the first quarter of this year compared with the same period last year, according to the attachment provided by the ministry.

;

;This followed a drop in price of 6.9 per cent from 2019-22, impacting China's domestic chemical industry, the association said.

;

;“To seize or maintain market share in China, US manufacturers have begun to adopt a price-cutting strategy to dump large quantities of propionic acid products into the Chinese market, and this has had a serious impact – and damaged – the domestic industry,” the ministry-issued document said.

;

;“If anti-dumping measures are not taken immediately, the domestic industry will suffer even more serious damage,” the Jiangsu association appealed in the document.

;

;As the world's biggest consumer market, China's demand for propionic acid has continued to rise in recent years, with its total consumption in 2022 increasing by 26. 7 per cent from 2019, according to the ministry.

;

;While the ministry's data shows that the US is China's main provider of propionic acid, with China's share of imports from the US rising from 97.41 per cent in 2020 to 100 per cent in the first quarter of this year.

;

;US tech curbs on China to 'travel towards tightening' despite pleas for calm

;

;Consumption of the chemical also increased by 3.5 per cent in the first quarter of 2023 compared with the same period last year, according to a report released in January by Newsjie.com, a Beijing-based market research group.

;

;The report said that since the easing of zero-Covid measures, infections have pushed up demand for ibuprofen, a fever-reducing drug with propionic acid as an intermediate.

;

;Nearly 60 per cent of China's propionic acid is used in agricultural grains and feed preservation, while Beijing's call for food security is likewise pushing up its domestic demand, according to data provided last year by Chyxx.com, a Shenzhen-based Research Consulting firm.

;

;When Washington initiated the trade war with China in 2018, propionic acid was listed as one of the chemical products subject to a 25 per cent tariff increase for China.

;

;Now Washington is stepping up its siege on China's tech sector, as it is considering new export restrictions on chips made by Nvidia and other chip companies to customers in China, the Wall Street Journal reported late last month.

;The federal judge overseeing former President Donald Trump's trial on his mishandling of classified documents case has set a trial date for May 20, rejecting the Justice Department's bid to try the case in December as well as the former president's request for a delay until after the 2024 election.

;

;Florida District Judge Aileen Cannon on Friday set the date following a closely watched pre-trial hearing on July 18. While prosecutors won't be able to try the case this year, Cannon's move is a setback for Trump, who had asked her to set no trial date as he navigates various trials, pending criminal probes and his campaign.

;

;The ruling places Trump's criminal trial less than six months ahead of the November 2024 US presidential election. The 77-year-old is the frontrunner for the Republican presidential nomination and the trial will be held at the height of the primary campaign to select the party's flag-bearer for the election.

;

;Cannon began her order by rebuffing Trump's request to delay setting a firm schedule, writing that she found it “necessary” to keep the rest of the case on track. She said that Trump's arguments in favour of delay rooted in the demands of his 2024 campaign were “unnecessary” to her decision.

;

;But she wrote that the government's December proposal was “atypically accelerated and inconsistent with ensuring a fair trial,” given the amount of evidence and complications related to the use of classified material.

;

;Trump goes on attack after pleading not guilty in classified docs case

;

;The trial in Florida is one of several legal obligations piling up on Trump's schedule going into the 2024 election cycle, including cases involving his business, allegations of defamation and hush money payments to an adult film star years ago. Trump is also the target of federal and state criminal probes related to efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election.

;

;The trial date falls after nearly all the primaries have been completed, but before an official Republican presidential nominee is named at the convention in July. If Trump won enough of those primaries, he could be the presumptive Republicans presidential nominee when his trial begins.

;

;Special counsel Jack Smith's office and the defence teams for Trump and his co-defendant Waltine “Walt” Nauta had all agreed that Cannon's original plan to hold the trial on August 14 was far too soon because they said they needed more time to prepare. But they sparred over what the judge should order instead.

;

;Federal prosecutors working for Smith at a hearing on Tuesday had asked Cannon to schedule the trial for December, while Trump's lawyers said there was no need to set a date yet.

;

;If the date holds, it would follow close on the heels of a separate New York trial for Trump on dozens of state charges of falsifying business records. It also means the trial will not start until deep into the presidential nominating calendar and probably well after the Republican nominee is clear – though before that person is officially nominated at the Republican National Convention.

;

;Trump could yet face additional trials in the coming year. He revealed this week that he had received a letter informing him that he was a target of a separate Justice Department investigation into efforts to undo the 2020 presidential election, and prosecutors in Georgia plan to announce charging decisions within weeks in an investigation into attempts by Trump and his allies to subvert the vote there.
